info.game_comments:
(Sarah: Remember the 2001 World Series?  We'll take you back to the bottom of the ninth, next on Jeopardy!)

Jeff Goldfarb sets a new single-day cash winnings record of $39,999.

(2, 1).clue: Similar to a relief map, a tactual map is designed for use by these people

(3, 1).clue: The Diamondbacks broke this Florida team's record as the expansion team to win a World Series fastest

(4, 1).clue: On Feb. 18, 1999 at Lincoln Center, this orchestra performed its 13,000th concert

(5, 1).clue: The region of Brie produced the Briard dog but is most famous for this food product

(6, 1).clue: Pass food or drink through the mouth & throat

(2, 2).clue: Photogrammetry is the science of making maps from photographs taken from these

(3, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew stands in the stands at Bank One Ballpark in Phoenix.)  Game 5 of the 2001 World Series was the first Major League game to be played in this month

(4, 2).clue: This city's orchestra began its Pops Concerts in 1885 under the name Promenade

(5, 2).clue: De Tocqueville called this event that changed world history "Inevitableyet... completely unforseen"

(6, 2).clue: If "ruffed" up, you might complain or grumble as this bird's name suggests

(2, 3).clue: The symbol seen here represents one of these; the Khyber & Donner are 2 of the most famous

(3, 3).clue: This lengthy lefty became the first pitcher to win games 6 & 7 of a World Series on consecutive days

(4, 3).clue: During WWII Allied bombs destroyed the Philharmonie, home to this German city's Philharmonic

(5, 3).clue: This figure seen here has an inflated sense of his own importance

(6, 3).clue: Mindlessly repeat the words of others

(1, 4).clue: In a letter to Josiah Quincy, Franklin wrote that "There never was a good war or" one of these

(2, 4).clue: Profession of Joshua Fry, who mapped Virginia, & of his subordinate George Washington

(3, 4).clue: This losing manager said philosophically, "You have to take both sides"

(4, 4).clue: This city's Philharmonic, formed in 1842, also plays regularly at the Salsburg festival

(5, 4).clue: Famed Socialist Eugene V. Debs was named for 2 socially conscious French authors: Eugene Sue & this man

(6, 4).clue: Figuratively, to prod someone into action

(1, 5).clue: "Three may keep a secret, if two of them are" this

(2, 5).clue: In mapmaking the Mercator is one example of this, a system of lines on a plane surface

(3, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew steps up to the plate & takes a swing at Bank One Ballpark.) In Game 7 of the 2001 World Series this player called "Gonzo" stood here & delivered the championship hit

(4, 5).clue: Eugene Goossens, first chief conductor of this city's Symphony, helped get the famous Opera House built

(5, 5).clue: This French term for a temporary residence means "foot on the ground"

(1, 1).clue: Samoa has 2 official languages: Samoan & this

(2, 1).clue: Guinness played this mythic character in the first 3 "Star Wars" films

(3, 1).clue: The 421 B.C. Peace of Nicias between Athens & the city-state was supposed to last for decades--didn't work

(5, 1).clue: A young girl's trial testimony against her rapist inspired his novel "A Time to Kill"

(1, 2).clue: (Jeff Probst delivers the clue from Nuku Hiva.)  Born in Paris, this artist lived in Peru as a child & died in the Marquesas Islands in 1903

(2, 2).clue: Guinness played many Shakespearean roles at this theatre aka the Royal Victorian Theatre

(3, 2).clue: Name given the 85 essays written by Hamilton, Jay & Madison that promoted the ratification of the Constitution

(5, 2).clue: In 1955 he got an offer he couldn't refuse: the publication of his first novel, "The Dark Arena"

(1, 3).clue: In 1957 remains of the H.M.S. Bounty were discovered off this tiny island

(2, 3).clue: It's the 1957 Best Picture winner for which Guinness won his best actor Oscar as Col. Nicholson

(3, 3).clue: This Empress' decree annexing the Crimea was issued on April 8, 1783

(5, 3).clue: Oui! Oui! in 1863 this science fiction pioneer published his first novel, "Five Weeks in a Balloon"

(6, 3).clue: In the 1838 Battle of Blood River, Andres Pretorius led troops against this African people's warriors

(1, 4).clue: (Jeff Probst delivers the clue.)  This author visited the Typee Valley on Nuku Hiva & his 1846 "Peep at Polynesian Life" is set here

(2, 4).clue: In a 1965 romantic epic, Guinness portrayed Yevgraf, the half-brother of this title physician

(3, 4).clue: The Tripartite Pact of 1940 allied Germany, Japan & this country

(5, 4).clue: Stephen Crane's first novel told the story of this "Girl of the Streets"

(6, 4).clue: This "Master of the Pan Flute" has sold millions of albums worldwide

(1, 5).clue: This kingdom's largest annual festival is Heilala, which coincides with the king's birthday on July 4

(2, 5).clue: Guinness received his first Oscar nomination for this 1951 comedy about a "Mob" that robs a bank

(3, 5).clue: Baron Eduard De Stoeckl for Russia & this man for the U.S. worked out the 1867 Alaska Purchase Treaty

(5, 5).clue: He wrote his first novel, "Junkie", under the pen name William Lee; "Naked Lunch" would follow

(6, 5).clue: This domesticated critter seen here has a dewlap & it do lap up lots of water when it gets thirsty

(0, 0).clue: In his job since 1984, this man has been called "the Prince who awakened Sleeping Beauty"
